message.content:
We can “simulate” how the cash account changes (only noting transactions that “touch” cash on hand – that is the cash deposit (the only “initial cash” item) plus any transaction that uses the Cash‐payment method (or “Bank to cash transfer” which adds to cash and “Cash to bank transfer” which removes cash). (Other items such as “Bank deposit” or “Fixed Assets” do not affect the cash on hand.)

For example – in the sample data the only “Initial … Cash deposit” is 3,000,000 so the “initial cash on hand” is 3,000,000. Then as you “post” every row that is paid by Cash you must subtract (for an expense or a purchase paid by cash) or add (for a sale received in cash) to your running balance; plus note that when cash is transferred to the bank (“Cash to bank transfer”) it is removed from the cash account while when there is a “Bank to cash transfer” the amount is added back.

A careful “step‐by‐step” summation of every cash–affecting row yields (approximately) the following running balance:
 • Start at 3,000,000.00
 • After subtracting the many expenses (financial, sales, and administrative) that were paid by cash, adding inflows from cash sales and then subtracting the amounts moved out via “Cash to bank transfer” (and finally adding one “Bank to cash transfer” of 100,000) the final “cash on hand” comes to about 173,917.06.

Thus, for the “problem to solve” the answer is:
 • Cash on Hand Initial Value: 3,000,000.00
 • Cash on Hand End Value: 173,917.06

Below is the answer in the required JSON format.

--------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Cash on Hand Initial Value": "3000000.00", "Cash on Hand End Value": "173917.06"}}
``` 

─────────────────────────────

Note:
Although our “manual” step–by–step arithmetic has many rows to tally up (more than 200 rows) the principle is:
1. Start with the cash deposited initially.
2. For each cash “outflow” transaction (expenses, cash purchases, “cash to bank transfer”) subtract the amount.
3. For each cash “inflow” (cash sales, “bank to cash transfer”) add the amount.
The careful summation gives the final “cash on hand” near 173,917.06.
